subject: RE: [junit] Concept of testing classes that implement Interfaces?

messageBody:
Nelson,

I think I prefer the cleanness of this way to test interfaces by Eric
George,
http://www.placebosoft.com/abstract-test.html

Given the method you describe below, the test class will become rather
large quite quickly each time a new implementing class is tested.
Eric's way allows a new unit test class to be added, therefore being
more modular.

Andy.

--
Andrew Beacock
Lammtara


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Nelson [mailto:nervousxians@...]
> Sent: 21 September 2003 23:25
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Concept of testing classes that implement Interfaces?
>
>
> Given that all classes {C} implement interface X, it would
> prolly be most logical to define test methods which all
> assert the successful functionality for an instance of every
> class in {C}. This way, we can be sure all implementations
> correctly work at runtime while reusing as much test code as possible.
>
> For example since classes {ArrayList, SortedSet} both
> implement interface Collection, the same tests can be applied
> to both :
> test_add()
> test_remove()
> ...etc
>
> Here is my plan on implementing this:
>
> I will have class AllImplTest extends TestCase which will
> have protected methods for each type of test. Using the
> Collections as an
> example:
>
> class AllImplTest extends TestCase
> {
> protected boolean test_add(final Collection inCollection)
> {
>
> }
> }
>
> The test_add will essentially test the inCollection to see if
> can successfully add an element.
>
> Then, I will have separate public methods to test each know
> implementation of the Collection interface eg
>
> public test_add_ArrayList()
> {
> ArrayList locArrayList=new ArrayList();
>
> boolean bSuccess=test_add(locArrayList);
>
> assertTrue(bSuccess);
> }
>
> This works great, but the only catch is, for every different
> type of implementation that is created, i'd have to add the
> test, no biggie though.
>
> What do you guys think about this?
>
>
>
